awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Travel Grant for 2022 Logic Programming and Non-Monotonic Reasoning Conference and Doctoral Consortium
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports student for select students participating in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium (DMC) at the 16th International Conference on Logic Programming and Nonmonotonic Reasoning (LPNMR) that will be held in Genova Nervi, Italy, September 5-8, 2022. This is a well-established international conference that facilitates interactions between researchers and practitioners interested in the design and implementation of logic-based programming languages and database systems, and researchers who work in the areas of knowledge representation and nonmonotonic reasoning. This activity will bring together a broad community of researchers in the field and support junior researchers at this critical early-career stage. The DMC creates the opportunity to bring in participants who might not have attended an AI conference due to lack of resources. This is especially true for those at smaller institutions and those which have less developed AI programs. Engaging such participants has the potential to draw more talent into AI research, improve research ideas in their formative stage, and engender collaborations across the breadth of disciplines. This event provides students with invaluable exposure to outside perspectives on their work at a critical time in their research and enables them to explore their career objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was (*) to support graduate students in the USA to attend the 16th International Conference on Logic Programming and Non-Monotonic Reasoning (LPNMR 2022) and the co-located Doctoral Consortium, which were held from September 5th to September 9th in Genova, Italy; and (*) to provide them with an opportunity to interact with senior researchers and industry personnel. Since the COVID-19 pandemic limited the ability for US-based students to attend LPNMR 2022, support from this grant was extended to the 17th International Conference on Logic Programming and Non-Monotonic Reasoning (LPNMR 2024), held in Dallas, TX, and the co-located Doctoral Consortium.

The LPNMR conference series, established in 1991, is driven by key researchers in the field of LPNMR, and attracts a substantial number of highly visible submissions. LPNMR is a forum for exchanging ideas on declarative logic programming, nonmonotonic reasoning, and knowledge representation. The aim of the conference is to facilitate interactions between researchers and practitioners interested in the design and implementation of logic-based programming languages and database systems, and those working in knowledge representation and nonmonotonic reasoning. LPNMR strives to encompass theoretical and experimental studies that have led or will lead to advances in these areas, as well as their use in practical applications.

LPNMR 2022 and LPNMR 2024 brought together researchers from LPNMR core areas and application areas in order to share research experiences, promote collaboration and identify directions for joint future research.To do so, LPNMR encouraged submissions on the foundations and implementations of LPNMR systems, and on applications of LPNMR. LPNMR 2022 included three workshops: 4th International Workshop on the Resurgence of Datalog in Academia and Industry (Datalog 2.0 2022), the first International Workshop on HYbrid Models for Coupling Deductive and Inductive ReAsoning (HYDRA 2022), and the 29th RCRA workshop on Experimental Evaluation of Algorithms for Solving Problems with Combinatorial Explosion (RCRA 2022). LPNMR 2024 was collocated with the 40th International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP 2024) and included one workshop: the 5th International Workshop on the Resurgence of Datalog in Academia and Industry (Datalog 2.0 2024).

The Doctoral Consortium has a long tradition in LPNMR conferences, and has always been a successful event, fostering the participation of doctoral students, exposing them to disciplines related to LPNMR, and putting them in direct contact with world-class researchers in the field.

The LPNMR Doctoral Consortium accepted nine (9) proposals from all around the world in 2022 and twelve (12) in 2024. Among them, one (1) student was from the US in 2022, and four (4) in 2024. Funding from this NSF grant was provided to them as travel and program registration awards. Additionally, two (2) other US-based students received travel awards to attend and present their papers at the main LPNMR 2024 conference, and three (3) at the LPNMR 2024 workshop titled Datalog 2.0 2024.

In 2022, each DC student submitted a 6-page long thesis summary, a curriculum vitae, a personal statement outlining what they hoped to gain from the DC and what unique perspective they hoped to contribute to the discussion, and a letter of recommendation from the thesis supervisor/ advisor. In 2024, each DC student submitted a cover letter including a statement outlining the reasons for applying to the DC and how it will benefit the applicant, and a 5 to 10-page research summary. Based on the materials submitted, each student was assigned a mentor, a senior researcher from the area of the students' research.

The LPNMR conference included a dedicated session for the DC and a lunch with the mentors. In 2022, an additional poster session was organized during one of the conference lunches, which gave the students the opportunity to present their work to all conference attendees and to receive feedback from them. In 2024, the DC was co-organized by LPNMR and ICLP, which gave the students the opportunity to present their research to a wider audience from the logic programming field.

These events allowed for a broad interaction with the general LPNMR conference and were also an opportunity for the students to discuss their research work with their mentors. Overall, the DC was a successful event that received positive feedback from students, mentors, and the LPNMR audience.
